content.question: A traffic engineer developed the continuous function <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, graphed above, to model the rate at which vehicles pass a certain intersection over an <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-hour time period, where <math alttext="R of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in vehicles per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of hours after 6:00 AM. According to the model, how many vehicles pass the intersection between time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and time <math alttext="t equals 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
